title: 115_hr2003
content: The "Pre-K for USA Act" is cited as the short title. It amends Title IX of the Every Student Succeeds Act by introducing local prekindergarten development grants. The "Pre-K for USA Act" establishes competitive grants for high-quality prekindergarten programs, awarded by the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Education for up to 3 years. Eligible local entities must provide non-Federal matching funds to receive the grant. Eligible local entities must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20 percent of the grant amount, which can be in the form of state funding, local funding, philanthropy, or in-kind contributions. The Secretaries have the discretion to waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing extreme financial hardship. The Secretaries may waive or reduce matching funds for eligible local entities demonstrating extreme financial hardship. Grants cannot be awarded if the entity's state has received a grant under another section for the same fiscal year. Definitions include early childhood education program and eligible local entity. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a high-quality prekindergarten program, which is supported by an eligible local entity and includes specific elements based on nationally recognized standards. It also defines a full-day as equivalent to a full school day in the state and not less than 5 hours. The curr_chunk outlines the standards for high-quality prekindergarten programs, including serving children aged 3 or 4, requiring high staff qualifications, and specifying teacher education requirements. The teacher in a high-quality prekindergarten program must have a bachelor's degree in any field, demonstrate knowledge in early childhood education, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a state-approved educator preparation program. The high-quality prekindergarten program requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree and demonstrate competence in early childhood education. The program maintains a maximum class size of 20 children, a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1, offers a full-day program, provides developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligns with state standards, offers competitive salaries, conducts ongoing monitoring and evaluation, and provides comprehensive services for children. The high-quality prekindergarten program offers accessible comprehensive services for children, including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development, family engagement opportunities, nutrition services, and assistance obtaining services when needed. The prekindergarten program offers nutritious meals and snacks aligned with Child and Adult Care Food Program guidelines, nutrition education for children and families, coordination with local educational agencies, and physical activity programs based on evidence-based guidelines. The prekindergarten program must provide high-quality professional development for staff, meet education performance standards, and maintain evidence-based health and safety standards. The prekindergarten program must meet education performance standards and maintain evidence-based health and safety standards. Authorization of appropriations is set at $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2019 through 2027. The table of contents in the Every Student Succeeds Act is amended to include State preschool development grants and Local prekindergarten development grants in sections 9212 and 9212A.
